To clarify, the system is not hanging during boot. The failure happens before POST.

Each time I press the power button, only the Caps Lock LED turns on for ~3 seconds and then the laptop goes completely dead again. Repeating this cycle multiple times over 5‚Äì10 minutes eventually allows the EC to complete power initialization and the system finally turns on.

This occurs before BIOS or any boot device is accessed, so no OS, disk, or filesystem activity is involved. Once the laptop powers on, it boots normally.

I ve confirmed this is a hardware power-initialization issue: the CPU fan has failed, and the previous Dell charger died due to a DC-side cable short (brick ‚Üí pin), which likely stressed the DC-in/EC circuitry. Because the issue is at EC/power-rail level, testing with another OS wouldn‚Äôt isolate it.

It sounds like it's an issue with the system swapping between the iGFX and Nvidia GPU. Other than a graphics driver issue, it could also be due to a Windows update. You could try using a system restore point to go back to a time before the issue started.

If you haven't already, uninstall both graphics drivers and reinstall. You can also try using the Nvidia control panel to set all actions to use the Nvidia card. This will reduce your battery life when you're not plugged in though.

The fact that the issue started after a system restart makes me think that it's a driver/update issue.

I would like to clarify that the issue is not limited to GPU switching or a Windows update.

The system experiences VIDEO_DXGKRNL_FATAL_ERROR (0x113), black screens, and visual artifacts while completely idle, with no applications running.

This occurs repeatedly, including after a clean OS reinstall and after servicing.

The following steps have already been performed:

Clean uninstall and reinstall of both AMD and NVIDIA graphics drivers
Testing with NVIDIA GPU only
System restart and clean environment
Device has already been serviced, yet the issue persists

Given that the crashes occur without load, after reinstall, and post-service, this strongly indicates a hardware-level fault, most likely related to VRAM or the GPU subsystem on the motherboard, rather than a driver or Windows update issue.

Hey [@Sifujon,](https://www.dell.com/community/en/users/69719cea918dc91cb4b53994) everthing good? So, maybe the issue is about the drivers, a Windows driver could be overriding the device one, so AWCC is not detecting it.

You can check it by following this steps:

- Open **Device Manager** (`Win + X` > Device Manager).
- Expand **Sound, video and game controllers**.
- Look for your headset.

  - **If it says "USB Audio Device"**: This is the problem.

  - **If it says "Alienware AW510H"**: The driver is present, but the AWCC service isn't talking to it.

If it is **"USB Audio Device"**, the generic one, try downloading and installing the device driver directly from the [Dell Support Page](https://www.dell.com/support/home/en-us).

Also, when you tried to reinstall the AWCC, did you do it like in [this video](https://www.dell.com/support/kbdoc/en-us/000178439/how-to-remove-and-reinstall-the-alienware-command-center)? There are some steps that make it a "clean installation", which should resolve any bugs or issues with it.

Hope it helps! üòÅ

When posting an issue with your computer please provide the computer model and the OS installed.

Troubleshooting Continuous Laptop Restarts

If your laptop is restarting continuously, follow these steps to diagnose and potentially resolve the issue:

1. **Check Power Supply**:

   - Ensure the power cable is securely connected.
   - Reseat the power cable and any external devices.
2. **Remove External Peripherals**:

   - Disconnect all external devices (USB drives, printers, etc.) and restart the laptop.
3. **Boot into Safe Mode**:

   - Try booting into Safe Mode to see if the issue persists. This can help determine if the problem is software-related.
4. **Check for BIOS Recovery**:

   - If your laptop supports BIOS recovery, follow the steps to initiate recovery. This may resolve issues related to BIOS corruption.
5. **Inspect for Hardware Issues**:

   - Look for any blinking LED patterns that may indicate hardware failures. Common patterns include:
     - **3 blinks, then 6 blinks**: BIOS corruption.
     - **3 blinks, then 7 blinks**: BIOS/CPU failure.
6. **Reset BIOS Settings**:

   - Access the BIOS by pressing F2 during startup. Restore BIOS settings to factory defaults.
7. **System Maintenance**:

   - Perform system maintenance to ensure optimal performance. Refer to Dell's optimization and maintenance resources.
8. **Contact Dell Support**:

   - If the issue persists after trying these steps, it may be necessary to contact Dell Technical Support for further assistance or potential repairs.

There is no Vostro 3265. If it's a 3565, which does exist it's a 2017 model long out of warranty.

No notebook is designed to be run 24/7 -- that alone will shorten its lifespan markedly. That includes not just the battery but all internal components.

It's safe in that the charging cuts off at 100% (or at whatever level you choose with the power manager -- there's no safety hazard.

No, there's no way to stop normal battery degradation. 18% in 16 months is pretty much normal -- the battery will last 2-3 years before it loses too much capacity to be useful.

When plugged in, the system uses AC power by default. Primarily AC reduces the charging duration to help with the battery lifespan.

Be sure you do occasionally use the system in battery only (unplugged). Other than that, and the fact that you're using the system for a duty cycle in excess of its design parameters, there should be no issue.

It no doubt can be done, but on a 2017 system, you're probably better off selling the system and buying a complete used one.  By the time you buy all the parts needed and particularly if you have to pay for labor, you'll spend far more than the system is worth.

A local computer shop can do the job if you're determined to have the swap made -- but Dell won't service a system that's now about eight years old.

The second monitor in the MST daisy chain should not need a MST setting.

All you have to do is set the first Samsung S27H850QFN DisplayPort:MST/DisplayPort:SST, [page 42](https://downloadcenter.samsung.com/content/UM/202410/20241025100648594/SH85_BN46-00575A-Eng_recycling.pdf).

My laptop is the same model as urs, and I used to suffer from the same issue. In short, change ur enclosure to something that equips with asm2464pd controller. Lunar lake laptops generally have serious compatibility issues with intel thunderbolt 3 controller. No way to fix but upgrading the enclosure to USB4 / TB4 controller. Hope this helps

I have an XPS 15 (9530). The two USB-C ports on the left stopped working yesterday. I had been having trouble for a couple of days. The light would go off on the power brick when I plugged in the cable. I did a hardware scan and I checked for updated drivers. Nothing came up. I had read that it might be a short circuit. Fortunately, the port on the right side was working. Right after I read your post, I checked to see if the other two ports still weren't working. Now they are both working! I did check for software updates and there were a couple that I took. (not sure why because I get the automatic updates).

Anyway, all of my ports are working now.

[@jostar1](https://www.dell.com/community/en/users/647bfb146f35e63b402b3ebf) ‚Äã
Thank you for the info. Unfortunately the 9315 has a bit different config and does not have any other ports, even traditional charging port, other than the two USB-C ports on each side.  So, if they are not working there is no way to charge.

If resetting the system as described doesn't help, chances are the Thunderbolt controller is dead. A shop such as parts-people.com can likely replace that (it requires board level repair). The only other option would be a replacement mainboard, which will cost more than a chip replacement.

Thank you all for the suggestions.
